lead_paragraph: New York City emerged from the weekend’s blizzard with relatively little damage, but the toll along the East Coast was more sobering: 29 deaths, thousands of homes without power and serious flooding.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Nicholas Fandos and Sheryl Gay Stolberg in Washington; Jon Hurdle in New Jersey; and Michael Barbaro, Mark S. Getzfred, Andy Newman, Emily Palmer, Noah Remnick, Nate Schweber, Ashley Southall and Jonathan Wolfe in New York.
byline.original: By JAMES BARRON and SARAH MASLIN NIR

snippet: New York City emerged from the weekend’s blizzard with relatively little damage, but the toll along the East Coast was more sobering: 29 deaths, thousands of homes without power and serious flooding.

headline.main: After East Coast Blizzard, the Cleanup and the Workweek Begin
headline.print_headline: A Long Cleanup in the Northeast

abstract: New York City appears to have weathered one of largest blizzards ever recorded as both Gov Andrew M Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio announce most mass transportation services have returned to normal operations for Monday morning commute; 29 people die across Mid-Atlantic and Northeastern states due to storm, and some areas report severe flooding and thousands of homes without power.
